title: Can you spot the problem with these headlines? (Level 1) - Jeff Leek and Lucy McGowan

multiple-choice.question: What is wrong with the headline "Study shows new drug could cure cancer"?

options.label: A
options.text: The study was conducted on humans instead of mice.

options.label: B
options.text: The study showed no results for women.

options.label: C
options.text: The subjects of the study were mice, so we can't draw conclusions about human disease based on this research.

options.label: D
options.text: The study had a small sample size.

multiple-choice.question: What is wrong with the headline "Aspirin may reduce risk of heart attacks"?

options.label: A
options.text: The study showed no results for women.

options.label: B
options.text: The study was conducted on animals instead of humans.

options.label: C
options.text: In this case, the study shows evidence that aspirin reduces heart attacks in men, but we can't assume that results found in men would also apply to women.

options.label: D
options.text: The study had a small sample size.

multiple-choice.question: What is wrong with the headline "Eating breakfast can help you lose weight"?

options.label: A
options.text: The people in the study started eating breakfast and lost weight.

options.label: B
options.text: The study was conducted on animals instead of humans.

options.label: C
options.text: We don't know that they lost weight because they started eating breakfast; perhaps having their weight tracked inspired them to change their eating habits in other ways.

options.label: D
options.text: The study had a small sample size.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main flaw with making general claims about human health issues based on individual studies?

options.label: A
options.text: The study had a small sample size.

options.label: B
options.text: The subjects of the study were mice, so we can't draw conclusions about human disease based on this research.

options.label: C
options.text: Big conclusions for human health issues require lots of evidence accumulated over time.

options.label: D
options.text: The study was conducted on animals instead of humans.

multiple-choice.question: What is the best way to bridge the gap between scientific studies and headlines?

options.label: A
options.text: Look at the original research behind a headline.

options.label: B
options.text: Read past the headlines and look for summaries of experimental design and results in freely available abstracts or within the text of a news article.

options.label: C
options.text: Ignore the headlines and only read about the study itself.

options.label: D
options.text: Assume that all scientific studies are accurate and reliable.
